item.title: Elon Musk says X plans to introduce ads in Grok’s responses
item.dc:creator: Aisha Malik
item.description: The move would help power X's struggling ads business following the departure of former CEO Linda Yaccarino.

item.title: Truth Social’s AI search is powered by Perplexity, but the platform can set limits on sources
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Bellan
item.description: The search engine, dubbed Truth Search AI, is already available on the web version of Truth Social, with public Beta testing on the iOS and Android apps planned for “the near future.”

item.title: Elad Gil — one of tech’s sharpest minds — on early bets, breakout growth, and what’s coming next at TechCrunch Disrupt 2025
item.dc:creator: TechCrunch Events
item.description: Elad Gil isn’t just ahead of the curve — he practically lives there. Before most of the world had even asked ChatGPT its first question, Gil was writing early checks into companies like Perplexity, Character.AI, and Harvey. And that’s just a slice of the story. His track record includes seed or Series A investments in […]

item.title: Data breach at French telecom giant Bouygues affects millions of customers
item.dc:creator: Zack Whittaker
item.description: This is the latest cyberattack to hit a French cellular carrier in recent weeks, following an attack on Orange Telecom in July.

item.title: Trump says Intel CEO Lip-Bu Tan must ‘resign immediately’
item.dc:creator: Ram Iyer
item.description: Trump's post comes after Republican Senator Tom Cotton on Wednesday wrote to Intel's board of directors, asking about Tan's ties to China, his investments in the country, and raised concerns about his time leading Cadence Design Systems, which had a Chinese military university as a customer.

item.title: Library of Congress explains how parts of US Constitution vanished from its website
item.dc:creator: Dominic-Madori Davis, Zack Whittaker
item.description: The U.S. congressional agency confirmed to TechCrunch that the removal of key sections of the Constitution from its website were removed in error. The full text has now been reinstated.

item.title: Hubble Network plans massive satellite upgrade to create global Bluetooth layer
item.dc:creator: Aria Alamalhodaei
item.description: Hubble Network's satellite-enabled Bluetooth network is getting a boost from Muon's new XL satellite bus.

item.title: The Browser Company launches a $20 monthly subscription for its AI-powered browser
item.dc:creator: Ivan Mehta
item.description: The Browser Company has its first paid plan in form of $20 per month Dia Pro.

item.title: Two teens charged in attack on former DOGE official Edward “Big Balls” Coristine
item.dc:creator: Connie Loizos
item.description: Two 15-year-olds have been charged with unarmed carjacking after allegedly attacking Edward "Big Balls" Coristine, the teenage software engineer and former Neuralink intern who became a prominent figure in the Trump administration's cost-cutting Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE).

item.title: Upwork is buying its way into corporate staffing beyond freelancers
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Szkutak
item.description: The company will merge Bubty and Ascen with its existing enterprise business to form a separate entity later this year.

item.title: Google denies AI search features are killing website traffic
item.dc:creator: Sarah Perez
item.description: Though Google hasn't shared any specific data to back up its conclusions, even if we assume Google's claims to be true, this doesn't necessarily mean that AI isn't having an impact.

item.title: TeaOnHer, a rival Tea app for men, is leaking users’ personal data and driver’s licenses
item.dc:creator: Amanda Silberling, Zack Whittaker
item.description: The newly launched app, now trending on Apple's App Store, contains at least one major security flaw that exposes the private information of its users, including their uploaded selfies and government-issued IDs.

item.title: Federal regulators give Zoox an exemption for its custom-built robotaxis
item.dc:creator: Kirsten Korosec
item.description: NHTSA is also closing an investigation into the Amazon-owned autonomous vehicle company.

item.title: How to actually raise a seed round: Actionable advice from top investors at TechCrunch Disrupt 2025
item.dc:creator: TechCrunch Events
item.description: This isn’t your typical venture panel. Expect sharp insights on how to cut through the noise, structure your raise, and build relationships that last beyond a term sheet. Whether you're gearing up for your first round or advising a founder who is, this is the TC Disrupt session you don’t want to miss.

item.title: First impressions of Alexa+, Amazon’s upgraded, AI-powered digital assistant
item.dc:creator: Sarah Perez
item.description: To find out whether Alexa is still the best smart assistant for my family, I'm going to test Amazon's AI-powered devices, experiment with AI queries, and write out my thoughts in a multi-part series.

item.title: Google takes on ChatGPT’s Study Mode with new ‘Guided Learning’ tool in Gemini
item.dc:creator: Aisha Malik
item.description: Google is also offering students in the U.S., Japan, Indonesia, Korea, and Brazil a free one-year subscription to its AI Pro plan.

item.title: OpenAI is practically giving ChatGPT to the government for free
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Bellan
item.description: GSA Federal Acquisition Service commissioner Josh Gruenbaum in a statement encouraged “other American AI technology companies to follow OpenAI’s lead and work with us.”

item.title: Google’s AI coding agent Jules is now out of beta
item.dc:creator: Jagmeet Singh
item.description: Powered by Gemini 2.5 Pro, Jules is an asynchronous, agent-based coding tool that integrates with GitHub, clones codebases into Google Cloud virtual machines, and uses AI to fix or update code while developers focus on other tasks.

item.title: Payment platform Lava raises $5.8M to build digital wallets for the ‘agent-native economy’
item.dc:creator: Dominic-Madori Davis
item.description: Lava is a digital wallet that lets merchants use credits to facilitate transactions.

item.title: Key sections of the US Constitution deleted from government’s website
item.dc:creator: Zack Whittaker, Dominic-Madori Davis
item.description: Internet sleuths say the U.S. Constitution's website is now missing key sections from its website, including a key legal provision relating to habeas corpus, which protects citizens from unlawful detention.
